data.title: Alphabet modulo
data.solution:
modulo = ord(input()) - ord("a")
string = input()
output = ""

for character in string:
    if not character.isalpha():
        output += character
        continue

    upper = character.isupper()

    index = ord(character.lower()) - ord("a")
    index %= modulo
    index += ord("a")

    output += chr(index).upper() if upper else chr(index).lower()

print(output)
data.statement:
You get a lowercase character [[c]] and a string [[s]]. Print [[s]] modulo [[c]].
Normally the modulo operation is only used for numbers. But you can also use it for characters.

<<Example:>> [[c]] = {{"g"}}
That means that after {{"f"}} comes not {{"g"}}, but {{"a"}}. Like this:
`a | b | c | d | e | f |
g | h | i | j | k | l |
m | n | o | p | q | r |
s | t | u | v | w | x |
y | z |`
Every character becomes the character in the same column in the first row: {{"g"}} = {{"a"}}, {{"h"}} = {{"b"}}, ...
Numbers and punctuation are not changed. An uppercase character remains in uppercase, a lowercase character remains in lowercase.

testCases.title: Special characters
testCases.testIn:
d
These are examples for characters, you shouldn't replace: !"§$%&/()=?{[]}\+#-.,;:_*'0123456789.
testCases.testOut: Bbbab acb bcaaacba ccc cbacacbbca, acc abcccab'b cbacacb: !"§$%&/()=?{[]}\+#-.,;:_*'0123456789.

testCases.title: Validator 4
testCases.testIn:
e
If you replace one of !"§$%&/()=?{[]}\+#-.,;:_*'0123456789, you won't pass the Testcase.
testCases.testOut: Ab aca baddaca cba cb !"§$%&/()=?{[]}\+#-.,;:_*'0123456789, aca ccb'd dacc dda Dacdcaca.

testCases.title: Long text
testCases.testIn:
l
Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consetetur sadipscing elitr, sed diam nonumy eirmod
testCases.testOut: Adgeb iehjb ddadg hii abei, cdcheieijg hadiehcicg eaiig, hed diab cdcjbc eigbdd

testCases.title: Validator 6
testCases.testIn:
n
At vero eos et accusam et justo duo dolores et ea rebum. Stet clita kasd gubergren, no sea takimata sanctus est
testCases.testOut: Ag ieeb ebf eg acchfam eg jhfgb dhb dblbeef eg ea eebhm. Fgeg cliga kafd ghbeegeea, ab fea gakimaga faacghf efg

data.stubGenerator:
read c:string(2)
read s:string(500)
write answer

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

You get a lowercase character c and a string s. Print s modulo c.
Normally the modulo operation is only used for numbers. But you can also use it for characters.

Example: c = "g"
That means that after "f" comes not "g", but "a". Like this:
a | b | c | d | e | f |
g | h | i | j | k | l |
m | n | o | p | q | r |
s | t | u | v | w | x |
y | z |

Every character becomes the character in the same column in the first row: "g" = "a", "h" = "b", ...
Numbers and punctuation are not changed. An uppercase character remains in uppercase, a lowercase character remains in lowercase.
Input
Line 1: A lowercase character c (not "a")
Line 2: The string s
Output
Line 1: s modulo c
Constraints
1 ≤ Length of s ≤ 500
Length of c = 1
c ≠ "a"
Example
Input
d
de
Output
ab
